An update on the Special Counsel`s investigation of Russia`s role in the last presidential election with Nick Confessore of "The New York Times"; The program continues with a report on the social media ads bought by Russia during the election with Alexandra Suich Bass of The Economist. Actor and director Griffin Dunne has a new documentary film starring her aunt Joan Didion. And Joan Didion was the most celebrated writers of the past 50 years

ALISON STEWART, JOURNALIST AND AUTHOR: Welcome to the program. Charlie Rose is on assignment. I`m Alison Stewart. We begin tonight with more on Russia`s attempts to influence the 2016 campaign.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, POLIIICAL INVESTIGATIVE REPORTER, THE NEW YORK TIMES: Bob Mueller knows a whole lot that we in the media and the public don`t know. He knows a lot. There was material -- you know, I`m very familiar with Paul Manafort`s business, his work in the Ukraine.

There was material in the indictment that I had never seen before, I had suspected. It was fascinating. You can get, when you`re a prosecutor like him, when you can get Cyprus to hand over banking records, you can get behind the veil, and Manafort really had cast a veil over his activities and was lying about them.

The Papadopoulos part, it just shows you there are not many leaks coming out of, you know, coming out of Mueller`s operation. I think a lot of the leaks are coming out of the fence, as they often do. He is running a very tight ship. And there is no -- I mean, some shoe will drop next, but it`s not clear which one.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ALISON STEWART: We conclude with Griffin Dunne, director of new documentary "Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GRIFFIN DUNNE, DIRECTOR: Throughout her whole life, the things she writes about is a world in disorder and eventually her life became a world of disorder, and -- and she`s trying to make these connections.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ALISON STEWART: Nick Confessore, Alexandra Suich Bass, and Griffin Dunne, when we continue.

CHARLIE ROSE (voice-over): Funding for "Charlie Rose" is provided by the following: Bank of America, life better connected.

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): And by Bloomberg, a provider of multimedia news and information services worldwide.

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): From our studios in New York City, this is "Charlie Rose."

ALISON STEWART: We begin tonight with politics, the special counsel`s investigation of Russia`s role in the last U.S. presidential election inch closer to the former Trump campaign. Money laundering and conspiracy indictments were handed down for former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his business partner Richard Gates. Both pled not guilty.

But the bigger news may be that a former campaign advisor, George Papadopoulos, pled guilty to lying to the FBI about his efforts to establish a relationship with the Russians. With me is Nick Confessore. He is a political investigative reporter for "The New York Times". Welcome, Nick.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Good to be here.

ALISON STEWART: So, let`s do the timeline for people. Manafort joins the campaign to help wrangle delegates at one point. That`s in March.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Right.

ALISON STEWART: In June, he takes over as campaign chairman. By August, he`s out.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Correct.

ALISON STEWART: So, all this has to do with the campaign, yet his indictment had to do with all of his the work in the Ukraine. Why is that relevant?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Well, what`s important here is that for years and years before he joined the Trump campaign, Paul Manafort was working abroad at the intersection of business and politics. He would export American- style campaign consulting to places like the Ukraine and then do business with oligarchs in the Ukraine and Russia.

He had his business ties. Where it connects is, as he was coming on the Trump campaign, he was still in contact with some of those oligarchs and some of his Russian contacts. And appeared that he owed a lot of debts or had financial relationships outstanding with some of these people in eastern Europe and in Russia.

And that is the crux of why there might be more here for the counsel. But the reason he`s in trouble right now is because as he was working for the Ukraine, he was lying about working for the Ukraine.

Under U.S. law if you`re working for a foreign power, you have to register in Washington and provide detailed disclosures. He did not do that. He claimed he was working for some center in London and it turns out in fact he was running the whole lobbying campaign for Ukrainian political party.

ALISON STEWART: This indictment was incredibly detailed. We found out about bank accounts. We found out he spent $850,000 on clothing in four years. That kind of detail, who is that giving pause to in the administration right now?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: That`s a great question. Look, I think that if you are in the inside in the White House right now, this is a terrifying time. Bob Mueller has access to tax returns. He was able to get bank accounts from Cyprus that Paul Manafort had access to. He was able to chart money flows.

So, if, as we know, the Trump family had business connections in Russia which was trying to do deals with them, was selling apartments to wealthy Russians, and if, as we know, people in the Trump orbits like Michael Cohen were doing a lot of business with people with money in Russia and Eastern Europe, it`s very easy to understand that Mueller is going to have access to all of that money flow.

He`s probably going to be able to see it and track it. And if there is anything that suggests a running financial relationship between Trump or his world and some of these interests, it`s going to show up.

ALISON STEWART: How wide (INAUDIBLE) does Mueller have?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Technically, it`s not that wide, right? But he is allowed to investigate crimes he discovers in the course of the investigation. So, he was not appointed to inquire as to whether Paul Manafort was working for the Ukraine and hadn`t registered under the Foreign Agents Act, but he did find that out in the course of investigating. And now there is a prosecution and a trial set for next year.

ALISON STEWART: Last week about this time, it was leaked that there would be an indictment. And over the weekend, I`m sure you heard a lot of people, who is it going to be? Is it going to be Flynn? Is it going to be Manafort? A lot of people thought it would be former national security advisor Michael Flynn. Do we know why it wasn`t? Were you surprised it wasn`t Flynn?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: You know, I had my money on either Flynn or Manafort and Gates, and the reason is those two guys or those three men are the lowest hanging fruit in the investigation. Paul Manafort was already under federal investigation for some of his activities in Eastern Europe and Ukraine and Russia. He was already under the gun.

And Flynn, we already know, had likewise not disclosed properly that he was working on behalf of a foreign government, in this case Turkey. That stuff has been reported. It`s been out there. There`s plenty of stuff on the ground for the prosecutors to look at. So I`m not surprised it would be some mix of that, but look, there are a bunch of sealed indictments in that courthouse that have not come out yet and we`re all waiting to see who`s next.

ALISON STEWART: The name that no one said last Friday was George Papadopoulos. I`m going to guess most people didn`t say George Papadopoulos. He`s a new player to a lot of people here. Who is he the most concerning for right now?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: I think he`s the most concerning for Donald Trump and Jeff Sessions. And the reason is, you know, you saw the first indictment or pair of indictments come out with Gates and Manafort. And instantly, the Trump White House said, see, no connection to Russia, it`s not about the campaign, it`s all a mess, it`s all bogus.

Then a few hours later out comes the Papadopoulos indictment and what it shows, actually more of a guilty plea, I should say, and what it shows is that, in fact, this was a named foreign policy advisor who sat in meetings with Sessions, sat in a meeting with President Trump, now President Trump, and was trying to arrange meetings back and forth with Russian interests and the Russian government.

ALISON STEWART: The Trump administration puts him basically an intern.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: It`s true. But, look, what we`re seeing here with Manafort and Papadopoulos and Sam Clovis who was also a foreign policy advisor but not a guy with a huge amount of expertise in foreign policy, what we are seeing is a side effect of the nature of Trump`s campaign.

He could not get the best people in Republican politics. He could not get the top shelf foreign policy advisers. So ended up with Carter Page, a guy who claimed to be an oil executive but actually works out of shared office space near Trump Tower, and Papadopoulos is a guy who falsified his credential on his resume which shows you the actual level of qualification.

So it`s true and fair to say this was not a heavy hitter, but he is one of the five people who the campaign at an early stage had put on its foreign policy committee and he was clearly empowered to be working on behalf of the campaign in setting his foreign policy and what we`ll find out is how much the other Trump officials, the senior officials on the campaign, knew about his intersections with and conversations with Russians.

ALISON STEWART: It also shown a light that Jeff Sessions misremembered again.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Yes, you know, Sessions has been kind of towing a careful line on recollections of meetings with Russians and Russian ambassadors and what we see here as he`s changed his story now, and it`s going to be -- again, really fascinating to see what the whole paper trail is.

We now know that there are pictures of the meeting and a lot will depend on what Sessions can credibly say about what he knew about the conversations and what kinds of permissions or authorizations Papadopoulos had and what he was kind of carrying back and forth in terms of information, offers, ideas.

ALISON STEWART: What does it say to you as an investigative reporter that no one knew about George Papadopoulos, or most people in the know didn`t know about him?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Well, you know, we knew who he was. We knew he was on the circle of the five foreign policy advisers, but I think --

ALISON STEWART: It didn`t leak even.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Well, it didn`t leak. And, look, that tells me that Bob Mueller knows a whole lot that we in the media and the public don`t know. He knows a lot. There was material -- you know, I`m very familiar with Paul Manafort`s business, his work in the Ukraine.

There was material in the indictment that I had never seen before, I had suspected. It was fascinating. You can get, when you`re a prosecutor like him, when you can get Cyprus to hand over banking records, you can get behind the veil, and Manafort had really cast a veil over his activities and was lying about them.

The Papadopoulos part, it just shows you there are not many leaks coming out of, you know, coming out of Mueller`s operation. I think a lot of leaks are coming out of the fence, as they often do. He is running a very tight ship. And there`s no -- I mean, some shoe will drop next but it`s not clear which one.

ALISON STEWART: Let`s talk about the court proceedings so far. We learned a lot of interesting things. Paul Manafort has three passports among them, they consider him a flight risk. He and Gates are both on house arrest. What else did we learn from Thursday`s court proceeding that we should pay attention to going forward?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Well, what we now learned aside from his vast wardrobe, apparently, was that he had set up transactions in Cyprus that are really fascinating. In some ways, the indictment lace out Paul Manafort as a case study on how wealthy Americans avoid taxation, hide their money.

So as investigative reporter, I was really fascinated by it. The simple trick is, you park your money in offshore accounts and you bring onshore just the stuff you want to pay or to avoid even that, you have your offshore companies pay your bills for you directly to your vendors, whether it`s the person who is decorating your house or somebody else.

So we really saw in great detail how that works. The other piece was those three passports, I suspect we`re going to hear more about them. Why did he have three passports? Well, sometimes you get an extra passport because, you know, let`s say you visited Israel as a business person and you want to visit some Islamic country or Muslim country that doesn`t like Israel, you may want a second passport where the entry and exit visas for Israel are not on it.

But once you have those multiple passports, it is possible to use them in an interesting way to cloak or hide the places you`re visiting from. You can use one passport to get to London, then take a flight to Cyprus with the other passport, for example, and you can hide a lot about your movements until somebody actually bothers to check and look, pull the passports and compare them.

So I suspect we`re going to hear more about what the purpose of those three passports was and I don`t think it was an accident or he lost the passport.

ALISON STEWART: The judge in this case was not amused, not pleased that there have been discussion in the media about the lawyers who went to the media. What do you think about the way that she is going to conduct the courtroom? How long do you think we`re going to be involved in this trial?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: It`s a great question. Look, I think Manafort and Gates are maintaining that the indictment is misleading, they`ve not done anything wrong, they`re going to fight it. The interesting question is whether these two men have enough money left to spend on lawyers to fight this kind of a case.

But, look, it`s going to proceed almost on its own track. You are going to see a case that is essentially built around tax evasion, money laundering, and failure to disclose working for a foreign power.

And what I`m really going to be focusing on and listening for is whether at some point the progress of that trial creates opportunities for or additional pressure for Mueller to use to get these guys to tell him more things about Donald Trump.

ALISON STEWART: What`s next in Mueller`s investigation, from where you sit?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Like I said, it`s a tight ship --

ALISON STEWART: OK.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: But what I see just based on the public facts, right, what you see is an experienced prosecutor doing two things, moving extraordinarily quickly, very, very fast. He indicted Paul Manafort within days, I believe, after getting the records from Cyprus of Manafort`s bank accounts.

And, two, he`s moving outside-in. He`s got Papadopoulos as a cooperating witness. It`s possible that he was actually cooperating in the investigation before the indictment was unsealed and the plea was unsealed.

There is a lot that George Papadopoulos could be saying, and we`ll find out whether there were any conversations he had while wiretapped with people in the Trump world. That`s going to be very interesting to find out. I suspect we`ll learn more about that in the months ahead.

ALISON STEWART: The obvious question everyone wants to know and wants to answer is how close it was, if there was Russian interference and collusion with the Trump administration, the inner circle. Outside of the obvious question, what`s the question that interests you?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: You know, the question that really, you know, I would say the question that I`m really intrigued by is whether -- so we know about two prongs of the Russian effort, right? One was to try to help maybe the Trump campaign, offer them damaging information on Hillary Clinton, sort of bolster his -- again, involved with him for various reasons.

The other was this social media information warfare campaign, setting up thousands or hundreds of fake pages and accounts on Twitter and Facebook and other social media platforms, using them to divide the country, push divisive content, target voters. A real open question that no one has been able to answer yet is whether those two efforts ever crossed paths.

Whether there was any exchange or collaboration between the Trump campaign in terms of its voter targeting and what the Russian intelligence agencies and proxies were doing to go after American voters. That I think is a critical, huge question.

ALISON STEWART: Aside from all this, the president`s duties go on. He`s about the take off on this long trip to Asia, five stops in eleven days. Will this investigation have an impact on that trip in any way?

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Look, it already has. He`s been tweeting about fake news and a hoax investigation within minutes of his planned departure on this trip. On the other hand, we`ve often seen that sometimes these trips are so busy for the president, that some of his instincts to engage, to get on Twitter, to start fights are a bit repressed, he doesn`t have time as much.

We saw that on his trips to the Middle East. The kind of Twitter (INAUDIBLE) quieted down for a couple of days. It`s possible we`ll see that. I`m not really sure if where he is really affects what Bob Mueller is doing on any given day.

ALISON STEWART: Nick Confessore from "The New York Times", thank you so much.

NICHOLAS CONFESSORE: Thank you.

ALISON STEWART: Some of the social media ads bought and paid for by Russia during the last election were on display in Capitol Hill this week and they were shocking. Representatives of tech giants Facebook, Twitter, and Google all testified before house and senate committees about Russia`s attempts to influence the 2016 campaign and what should be done to prevent it from happening again.

Alexandra Suich Bass joins me now from San Francisco where she covers the tech industry for The Economist. Alexandra, what were the main questions the senators wanted answered during this testimony?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS, U.S. TECHNOLOGY EDITOR, THE ECONOMIST: The senators are really interested in the extent of the Russian campaign and they`re trying to get their heads around it. Initially, the tech giants were very evasive and really underplayed the threat that Russians had manipulated Americans in the lead up to the 2016 election.

They then come forward and said that they have found evidence that there were fake accounts and bots, ads that were directed at Americans that we are seeing before which might have influenced their votes.

And so the senators were really pressing the tech giants, one for details about how widespread the manipulation went. And then the other question was what the tech giants are going to do to make sure that nothing like this happens again particularly in the 2018 election.

ALISON STEWART: Did the tech giants offer any details?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: The tech giants showed us some of the ads and fake accounts for the first time. There were some really fascinating ones. For example, Hillary Clinton dressed up as the devil battling Jesus. And it was said, if you want Jesus to win, like this ad. And, of course, then if you have liked it or engaged the ad, you can be targeted again for some similar material.

We`ve seen that around 150 Americans, which is a huge percentage of Americans, were exposed to this content on Facebook and Instagram. So, in the hearings, we were able to see, A, the extent of the Russian messaging and, B, some of the specific messages, which I think were surprising in their directness.

ALISON STEWART: It`s sort of interesting in Washington, the hearing, the tech giants and senators seem to be talking past one another, because the tech folks kept saying, but we`re a platform, it`s sort of the "I don`t recall" of the tech industry. Explain why they want to stay with that "we we`re just a platform" saying.

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: Right. It`s kind of similar to the NRA that says, you know, guns don`t kill people, other people kill people. They basically don`t want to have any responsibility for how their tools are being used, the internet giants in this case.

They are very wary -- I think they`re being cautious, but they also have good reason to be. So, if you look at internationally how platforms are being used, they get constant take down requests from authoritarian governments or requests for more information about users.

So from Turkey, for example, Egypt. So they have to really be careful in establishing the precedent, that they`re willing to comply with governments in that regard, or that they`re responsible for hate speech or anything like that that occurs on their platforms.

So that`s why they`re saying we might accept advertising but we`re not your typical media company. I think where their response was really insufficient is Facebook especially has done this audit where they found a few thousand ads, they say, that were paid for in rubles.

I think that`s kind of the equivalent of saying, you know, the police investigate crimes based on which homes doors have been left open -- the front door has been left open.

And looking just at rubles as a sign of when the Russians were responsible for adds I think is really insufficient. And something that the senators didn`t get at is to ask for a complete audit of all ads.

Facebook, Twitter and Google offer really sophisticated tracking tools when it comes to marketers and advertisers, so companies like Coca-Cola or Unilever, for example, but in this case they`re deflecting their ability and downplaying their ability to really do a full audit.

ALISON STEWART: Many of the senators seemed unsatisfied with many of the answers that they got. Senator Feinstein particularly said, you do something or we will, to these giants. Should they be afraid of that threat? What could she do? What could congress do?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: So, I think that there`s tremendous frustration and the general counsels who were there, not their CEOs, were trying to be humble, but did deflect a lot of questions, a very pointed questions. So I think that frustration bubbled over among the senators.

When it comes to action, I do think that there is real disconnect between the rhetoric right now and the feeling that America has been betrayed by the large tech giants and a disconnect from what they`re really able to do. So, right now, there are a couple of things being considered.

One is to propose -- there has been a bill proposed that would require more transparency when it comes to political advertisements, basically bringing digital ads up to the same standards that television ads and ads on other media are held to. I think that`s very sensible.

The tech giants are saying actually that, you know, they`re broadly in favor of transparency and they`re actually going to implement more transparency and disclosure about who`s paying for ads on their own, but that they`re not quite sure about the details of the regulation -- the proposed regulation and whether or not they will support it.

And then, of course, this week, we saw a proposal for tax reform which would be highly favorable to the tech giants by lowering the corporate tax rate. And, so, on one side, you hear these very angry, disappointed claims coming from the senators, and then you have the reality that there is not that much that`s being suggested that looks close to passing that could change their fortunes or behavior.

ALISON STEWART: Let`s look at the optics of what we saw. We did not see familiar faces sitting behind that table. In fact, one editor at the Columbia Journalism Review tweeted, tech CEOs will show up for magazine covers, Davos, Burning Man, Game of Thrones, (INAUDIBLE) parties, just not senate hearings. We did not see Zuckerberg, we did not see Sandberg, we did not see Twitter`s Jack Dorsey. What was that about?

ALISON STEWART: Well, it was actually even more pointed, so not only did they not show up, but Mark Zuckerberg was at Facebook headquarters in Silicon Valley on an earnings call announcing record profits and revenues and seeing Facebook shared prize surge. So it was a day of dissident realities, if you will.

I think if you`re looking at the tech giants` interests which is to not submit your CEO to very hostile questions and give journalists the ability to talk about Mark Zuckerberg`s or Jack Dorsey`s humbling in front of the senators, they made the right choice in sending their general counsels there, who were excellent lawyers at talking around the issues and sometimes not answering very specifically.

But I know it disappointed the senators. And I wouldn`t say that it`s out of the question that there would be another hearing where the tech bosses might be forced to show if we get more investigations and disclosures into the extent of the interference. We might have a second act.

ALISON STEWART: Something that you have been reporting about at The Economist is sort of the isolation of these tech giants. They don`t necessarily feel aligned at this point with the Democratic Party or with the Republican Party. What happened that they ended up being a little bit on an island to themselves in terms of political power and political capital?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: It`s exactly right. They really are an industry with no political party. They used to be able to depend on the Democrats for sympathy because Democrats, I think, were very tech forward under President Obama`s administration, a lot were put in top seats, they had given heavily to the Democrats.

But Democrats really feel betrayed by the tech platforms. They feel like the Russians were able to influence the outcome of the 2016 election for the worst because of the company`s lack of oversight of advertising and fake accounts. So, the Democrats have turned away from tech.

And the Republican Party today isn`t as predictably anti-regulation as they used to be, and because of the populist strains going through both parties right now, it`s playing really well to criticize tech and you see, actually, Senator Elizabeth Warren on the left and others on the right, Steve Bannon, talk about regulating tech as utilities are breaking up big tech.

And so, again, that goes to the rhetoric. I write about it as a tech-lash in Washington, a tech backlash. But it`s unclear that either side really wants to own the tech industry and work on their behalf right now.

ALISON STEWART: And we shouldn`t suggest the tech industry is doing a rope- a-dope and sitting this out. They are spending enormous amounts of money on lobbyists, correct?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: They are. In one sense there, they are very well positioned, because these are incredibly successful and profitable tech companies, they have a lot to spend and they have learned from the mistakes of their predecessors. So, what Microsoft didn`t do well and why they ultimately saw a lot of backlash in Washington is they didn`t manage their Washington relationship early.

So Google and Facebook were a lot earlier to put people in Washington, set up large offices. We see Amazon doing the same thing. The reason they`re in a difficult position is there`s a few reasons. One is that their interests are all so diverse. So some tech companies are coming out in support of issues, others against it.

And so you see that with something that`s being proposed right now that would hold tech companies responsible for sex trafficking that occurs on their platforms with heavy fines. Oracle, a tech giant from the Valley is actually in support of it. Google isn`t. and so you see a disconnect amongst the giants of what`s in their interests.

And a further problem is that they have to lobby a lot of different government agencies. Unlike, say, pharmaceuticals where, you know, you know that you really need to be on top of the FDA and what they`re considering.

Tech is regulated by so many different groups, the FTC, the FCC, and others. And so, they in the past have really struggled to focus their attention and know exactly where to put it to avoid push back and manage the reputation.

ALISON STEWART: And to circle back to my last question to what we first started talking about. Obviously, these hearings were about the 2016 election and Russian interference, but this could really go to any kind of false information being put on these platforms. That`s actually the big picture issue, right?

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: Yes. I think the big picture issue right now and we actually have it on our cover for The Economist this week is, is social media bad for democracy? A few years ago, there were so much optimism that platforms like Facebook and Twitter and Google and You Tube, the online video site, would help with really democratic movement, kind of include new voices that weren`t possible to hear through established media.

And we did see some of that. We saw it in the Ukraine. We saw it in Egypt. And then, today, I think we`re seeing the dark side of social media. We`re seeing how these platforms can be used for bullying, for abuse, for terrorists and other extremist content, for hate speech.

And so I think the big picture is, is social media going to bring us together or pull us apart, and are we able to get social media firms to take responsibility so that their platforms can be used for good rather than for evil.

ALISON STEWART: Alexandra Suich Bass from The Economist, thanks so much.

ALEXANDRA SUICH BASS: Thank you for having me.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: ... could make sense.

CHARLIE ROSE: Did she feel greater -- as she began to write both journalism and novels, did she feel one was more her metier than the other?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I think -- I think she started as a non-fiction writer and I think that that`s -- I mean, she loves stories. You know, in novels she like -- she writes and she doesn`t know where her novel is going to go.

(CROSSTALK)

CHARLIE ROSE: We`re sitting here talking about her like she`s somewhere.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: She`s probably going to watch television to see this. Hi, Joan. But, you know, I think her interest is always particularly strong in essays and nonfiction and writing about politics and...

CHARLIE ROSE: Bob Silver helped her plan politics.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Absolutely.

CHARLIE ROSE: Bob Silver is one of the famous editors who recently died as well. And other we know (Inaudible), and other`s he played roles in this world of media.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yes and he was -- he was someone that said, Joan, how would you like to go to Salvador and write about this brutal civil war? And she -- and she leapt to it. And he seemed to know, from reading her earliest essays, that she would actually make a beautiful transition into writing also about American politics but she really didn`t -- not that she didn`t have any interest, she just didn`t think that would be her strong suit.

CHARLIE ROSE: Her strong suit was culture or something else?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I think her strong suit was more personal -- the personal essay of her confronting, you know, everything from being a mother to, you know, things that would be these insights that she would have that other people would relate to so strongly in their own lives.

She saw that your actually -- you could write about Cheney, such a devastating piece that he should be hiding under a bed from the moment he reads it, you know. And just have character insight into, you know, deciphering the message that the politicians don`t want you to hear and what the media is really saying, the underlying message. That turned out to be her strongest talent in her political -- in writing about Salvador.

CHARLIE ROSE: How does she differ from Oriana Fallaci?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I think she`s -- Oriana Fallaci hardly an expert on her book, reading her essays and her interviews, I think she`s much more aggressive, you know? Kind of...

CHARLIE ROSE: Clearly that.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And more assertive and is very much on the equal plain. Joan is -- Joan is quieter and I think that quietness of world, she`s very comfortable and makes other people talk to her. And you know, that`s why she likes writing about musicians because, you know, they`re just let it all unfold. So she could hang out with Morrison, and Morrison probably wasn`t the effusive speaker either, and very enigmatic kind of difficult personality, but, I don`t know, they were meet, Joan, and they`d open up.

CHARLIE ROSE: She and John Dunne, how long were they married -- for how long?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: They were married in 1960.

CHARLIE ROSE: I love the fact that you would go to restaurants and you see them together eating.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah.

CHARLIE ROSE: And you would see them and -- I always watch this when I`m in New York and I go out to eat. Are they talking to each other? They were always talking to each other.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: It was like, they just carried the conversation all from the cab.

CHARLIE ROSE: From the house to getting to the cab, to getting at the restaurant.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah. I mean they were just constantly -- they were just always interested in each other, and, you know, there`s another thing about John and Joan being in a restaurant. You know, people often never believe that they weren`t, you know, competitive. And, you know, one more famous than the other and, you know, being, you know, competitive in that way. John was very -- when John would be at Ellio`s (ph), for example.

CHARLIE ROSE: That`s why you would see him more that anyone else.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Exactly. And when he went to Ellio`s, if he saw someone craning to see Joan and saw that he was blocking their view, he would move.

CHARLIE ROSE: That`s great.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I just love that about John.

CHARLIE ROSE: I do, too. Once there was a time in which they thought they might divorce.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah, which we found out by reading Life Magazine, the famous piece that was -- that she wrote while -- during an oncoming tsunami in Honolulu, she is there, Quintana is very young, and she and John are there mulling over whether they should split.

And she makes this equation between the seismic shifts outside the window of their hotel room and what`s going on between them, and we as family members, and my parents and brother, and sister, we had no idea. They`ve always been John and Joan, one word.

CHARLIE ROSE: Absolutely. They read everything each other wrote?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And they read -- so John actually edited that piece. I mean she wrote it about thinking of getting a divorce, leaving my husband.

(CROSSTALK)

GRIFFIN DUNNE: How do you like it? Do you think that paragraph is good? I don`t know. Not so sure.

(LAUGHTER)

CHARLIE ROSE: It`s unbelievable.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: It`s incredible. I love that.

CHARLIE ROSE: And when she found out she had -- she was going to have Quintana -- I mean when Quintana was born, she gets a call from the hospital?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yep. They had been -- it was like a call just out of the blue. I think they weren`t really thinking about it a whole lot. They wanted to have a child, they couldn`t have a child, and one of their friends knew the gynecologist at the hospital, and this guy just called and said, we have this baby in St. John`s Hospital, and they got in the car right away, and they...

CHARLIE ROSE: Went and picked the baby up?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: They picked the baby up and they drove home on 405, and Joan bonded with Quintana there as, you know, a two-day-old infant.

CHARLIE ROSE: And then John dies -- heart attack.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Heart attack. Heart attack. He`d always had heart issues. His ticker, as he would call it.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yeah.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And, you know, he would write about it, of course. You know, he became fascinated with the valves and all the arteries that would go through -- through his body. He wrote about it quite beautifully, almost like -- he compared it to music and the symphony of the body.

But, you know, Quintana, on Christmas Eve, was admitted to hospital with septic shock and that was very serious, and the -- I think the trauma of his worry for Quintana brought on the heart attack, and it was sudden and unexpected and, as John writes, you know, life changes in an instant.

CHARLIE ROSE: This is -- go to clip four. This is from this show. This is Joan talking about writing, the year of magical thinking, which is the book about that year. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: This is probably the first book you`ve ever written without John.

JOAN DIDION: Yeah. It is the first book. I had written a couple of pieces before I did the book -- I mean after he died but before I did the book, but this is certainly the first book. I mean, my first novel was written before we were married, but he still read it.

CHARLIE ROSE: But he would read everything.

JOAN DIDION: He would read everything

CHARLIE ROSE: You talked to him.

JOAN DIDION: Yeah. Yeah. So that`s something I miss because he would give me a sense of being safe, you know. If he said it was OK, then I would proceed. And if he said it wasn`t OK, then I would rewrite.

CHARLIE ROSE: And you do the same thing for him?

JOAN DIDION: Yeah. So that was kind of a thing -- you grow to rely on that. And at the time -- you know, at the time it happened -- and they said to me, why you are going to rely all that. You can develop new readers. Well, it doesn`t -- it`s not really the same, you know. Nobody else has that investment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: This is another clip. This is clip number three. She`s on this show and she is talking about how she learned the rhythm of writing. Here it is. This is in 2000 -- this is 1992.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Oh, my.

CHARLIE ROSE: Goodness, gracious. 1992.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOAN DIDION: I taught myself how to type. You know, I`m not a touch typist. I still do it this way. But I taught myself how to type by typing sentences, typing out Hemingway`s sentences over and over again.

CHARLIE ROSE: Looking for?

JOAN DIDION: Just how they worked, because they appeared to be so simple, but you would come away from a string of them with these overwhelming feeling of whatever he had in mind for you to feel. So, I mean, obviously, something was going on in the sentences.

CHARLIE ROSE: People...

JOAN DIDION: You know what was going on. It was -- it was a withholding. There was withheld information in these sentences, and it had to do with a rhythm. I mean, I can`t exactly explain it.

CHARLIE ROSE: But you got it.

JOAN DIDION: Yeah.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Well, then, she described what she`s famous for, the withholding.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And, you know, learning to do that by typing Hemingway`s sentences is kind of a genius, you know.

CHARLIE ROSE: There is a famous story, which I do not know whether it`s true or not and I want to believe it so badly. It is that Hunter Thompson was at the public library and somebody happened to be there, and went over and said, Hunter, what are you doing? And he was reading Shakespeare. And they said, what? He said, I`m trying to get the rhythm.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: No kidding! I want to believe that, too.

CHARLIE ROSE: Don`t you want to believe that?

(LAUGHTER)

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I`m sure he was reading something really bloody, too. I`m sure.

CHARLIE ROSE: And then the death of the daughter.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah, Quintana. You know, it was -- you know, it was from -- it took her weeks to recover from the first visit to the hospital after septic shock, and so, the funeral for John wasn`t going to happen until she was able to attend. And she wanted to go to California, to go to Malibu with her husband Jerry. They were newly married.

But it was like the next day, she was already quite frail, you know. She had just been out of the hospital. And the plane lands in Los Angeles and she falls and hits her head, and goes back into coma, and from which required a great deal of physical therapy to get past it when she came out of the coma.

You know there was -- and she was, you know, in a wheelchair and she had to learn how to walk and move, and it was, I think, just a part of her just started to sort of break down. And just -- she just really didn`t want to be around much longer.

CHARLIE ROSE: What do you want us to come away from in this documentary?

GRIFFIN DUNNE: I want people to feel that they`ve witnessed a life lived, someone who -- someone who you know, came from descendents of homesteaders, who -- you know, it`s very significant...

(CROSSTALK)

CHARLIE ROSE: The Donner Party.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Who came out with the Donner Party...

(CROSSTALK)

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And this is John`s character -- you don`t take short cuts.

CHARLIE ROSE: Exactly.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And it`s a -- it`s a morality that she`s lived her whole life by, and she is -- you know, she`s outlived all her friends for a reason. She`s, like, from strong western stock.

CHARLIE ROSE: What is amazing, when you would hold her arm, it`s like this thin.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah.

CHARLIE ROSE: And I`m afraid I`m going to...

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Yeah.

CHARLIE ROSE: And yet you know that, within her, is a strong -- like a bull.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: No, I mean, I see -- you know, I see a John Wayne movie in that soul. I mean I see, you know, cattle ranches and, you know, just people.

CHARLIE ROSE: All that stuff from the west.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: All that stuff from the west. I mean -- and I wouldn`t have seen that had I not made this movie, you know. She was -- she was my aunt and John`s wife, and who I`ve known all my life.

But I saw -- and I`ve grown up hearing about her, you know, described as, you know, bird-like but strong and fierce on the inside. But I really saw that. You know, it`s something I will never unsee. You know, I see that strength inside of her like I never had before.

CHARLIE ROSE: The title is The Center Will Not Hold.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: The paraphrasing of The second Coming, The Yeats poem.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: And you know she wrote about it. She used it in slouching towards Bethlehem, her most famous essay in the `60s and, you know, -- she was writing about -- everybody else was writing about peace and love, and the hippie movement and, you know, everybody riding around the Volkswagen bugs.

And she goes there, and she`s looking at families that are falling apart, she`s looking at runaway children, she`s looking at the center of families, of the fabric that, you know, had been pretty strong in the `50s when she was growing up and before then and, here, the `60s had come along and, you know, society just was falling apart at the seams, and that whole decade was one of just massive chaos.

CHARLIE ROSE: Thank you for coming.

GRIFFIN DUNNE: Thank you for having me.

CHARLIE ROSE: Griffin Dunne. Joan Dion and the film was called, The Center Will Not Hold. Thank you for joining us. See you next time.

For more about this program and earlier episodes, visit us online at PBS.org and Charlierose.com.

urn:contentItem:5H9D-GC61-DXH2-62GD-00000-00Conversation with Tom Wheeler; Conversation with Meg Whitman2015-11-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:26ZLexisNexisTHE CHARLIE ROSE SHOW11:00 PM ESTTom Wheeler, Meg WhitmanNEWS110301cb.111Conversation with Tom Wheeler; Conversation with Meg WhitmanCharlie Rose

Tom Wheeler is chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the agency adopted net neutrality rules earlier this year; the new regulations treat Internet service as a public utility, the commissioner has also been active in reviewing media and telecommunications mergers. Meg Whitman has been CEO of Hewlett Packard since 2011, the technology icon was created more than 75 years ago in a Palo Alto garage, for decades it led in the business of selling computers and printers; the growth of enterprise services has forced HP to evolve, the company`s reinvented itself with aspirations to capitalize in both the PC and networking solutions arena.

CHARLIE ROSE: Welcome to the program.

Tonight: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM WHEELER, FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION CHAIRMAN: I ran the Cable Television Association when it was an up and coming industry being and fighting for survival. I ran the cellular industry, you know, a dozen years ago when it was an entirely different business. I`ve started my own businesses. I have been a partner to venture capital firm helping start businesses.

So I come to this job with an understanding of both business and policy and how it works with the people that we regulate. So I actually think I come with a leg up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: We conclude with Meg Whitman, formerly the CEO of eBay, now the CEO of Hewlett Packard.

MEG WHITMAN, HEWLETT PACKARD CEO: I found a very proud company with incredible founder DNA. The a-ha here is, and this is great news for any founder that`s watching your program, it is really hard to kill founder DNA.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yes.

MEG WHITMAN: And for HP, that was a very good thing because the core of this company through all the acquisitions and all the board drama was around innovation and focus on customers.

And so I made the decision, let`s do more of what we do well, and then we`ll work on the to-do list of things that need to be fixed. And there were a number of things that need to be fixed.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: Tom Wheeler and Meg Whitman, when we continue.

ANNOUNCER: From our studios in New York City, this is CHARLIE ROSE.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHARLIE ROSE: Tom Wheeler is here. He is chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. The agency adopted net neutrality rules earlier this year. The new regulations treat Internet service as a public utility. The commissioner has also been active in reviewing media and telecommunications mergers.

This summer it approved AT&T`s takeover of DirecTV which created the largest television distributor in the United States. Next year the FCC will hold an auction to coordinate the sale of television air waves.

For all those reasons I`m pleased to have Chairman Tom Wheeler at this table for the first time. It seems like I`ve known him for 100 years. It`s a pleasure to have you.

TOM WHEELER: Charlie -- thank you. It`s great to be here.

CHARLIE ROSE: And we had your favorite Ohio State coach here the other day and --

TOM WHEELER: From the Ohio State University.

CHARLIE ROSE: From the Ohio State University. My impression is they have no bigger or stronger fan than you.

TOM WHEELER: I think that`s a true statement.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yes. And you used to work with Woody Hayes.

TOM WHEELER: Yes, way back when, when I was in graduate school I had the privilege of being able to rub shoulders with Coach Hayes and some of the things he was doing in the state. He was a great --

CHARLIE ROSE: I would imagine you had lots to talk about military history and all the things that he taught there.

TOM WHEELER: Yes. And three yards and a cloud of dust -- that`s the way he ran. You know, three things can -- why don`t you pass coach? Three things can happen and two of them were bad.

CHARLIE ROSE: So what can happen to the FCC?

TOM WHEELER: Well, you know, Charlie we`re sitting at a really exciting time in history if you stop and think about it. The most important external force in our daily lives are the networks that connect us, and we at the FCC get the privilege to be involved in the evolution of those networks into the digital era, whether it`s broadcasting or cable or satellite or telephone networks or the Internet. That`s our jurisdiction.

It`s about a sixth of the economy that we get a chance to participate with as they`re evolving from the old analog world to the new digital world.

CHARLIE ROSE: And so -- but what do you do? I mean you obviously hear important arguments and make rulings on them.

TOM WHEELER: Well, you know, the really interesting thing about this job is that the statute was written in 1934. It was updated in 1996. And even from 1996, a lot has changed. So the challenge that we have is to say, OK, let`s look at the basic four corners that the Congress has laid down and said this is what we think is in the public interest, and then make interpretations as to how that statutory responsibility works in the new digital world.

And so we`re dealing with everything from mergers to competitive issues and how do you make sure that there is competition in these markets? How do you make sure that there is consumer protection? How do you make sure that national security is protected? So it`s a very broad palette that we have to work with.

CHARLIE ROSE: This is what predecessor Michael Powell, president of the National Cable Communications Association and the chairman of the FCC in the Bush administration said quote, "The commission has breathed new life into the decayed telephone regulatory model and applied it to the most dynamic free wheeling and innovative platform in history."

TOM WHEELER: Well, I agree totally with him. The Internet is the most dynamic and free wheeling platform in history.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

TOM WHEELER: It`s the most powerful and pervasive platform in history.

I disagree entirely with him because on his other part because, basically, what the cable industry and the telephone industry and those who provide Internet service, last-mile service, have been saying is, oh, leave us alone, leave us alone.

What we did was we said, wait a minute -- there is a basic responsibility that people who are providing Internet service have to make sure that consumers have unfettered access to the content they want to go to on the web and that those who are creating content have unfettered access to consumers, and that`s some basic things.

There should be no blocking. You should not be able to say you can get through when you can`t. There should be no throttling. You shouldn`t be able to say, well, your service, I`m not going to allow it to go as fast as another service. There should be no paid prioritization. You shouldn`t be able to say well, you`re a fast lane and you`re a slow lane, because you`re paying me more.

And then what you need to have in place is I think the thing that they`re really most concerned about and that is you need to have a referee on the field. We were talking about Woody Hayes and Urban Meyer a minute ago.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

TOM WHEELER: You need to have a set of rules that says is this just unreasonable and you need to have somebody who can throw the flag if it isn`t. We don`t know what the Internet is going to become five years from now. I mean think back five years and where we are today. We had no idea it would end up today. What we don`t want to have happen as a regulatory agency is to thwart innovation. But at the same point in time, we don`t want those who are --

CHARLIE ROSE: That`s one of the arguments they made.

TOM WHEELER: But the other part is we don`t want people who are running the networks to have to be the ones who provide permission for innovators and entrepreneurs to provide new services. So it`s the concept of permissionless innovation and making sure that there is somebody to say does this make sense? Is this just and reasonable?

CHARLIE ROSE: OK. But their argument is that you inhibit innovation. That`s where they --

TOM WHEELER: But I think that that is easily refuted by you look at the tremendous growth in investment that has taken place in entrepreneurial activities since we put the rules in place. You look at how the industry, the cable industry, the telephone industry, the wireless industry have unprecedented levels of investment since we put the rules in place. I mean the network itself is growing and those who serve the network is growing since we put in the rules.

CHARLIE ROSE: So if you make a huge capital investment to provide the fastest Internet service somewhere, you now simply have to make that available to everybody.

TOM WHEELER: Correct.

CHARLIE ROSE: When John Oliver was on this program he talked about the story of someone with your experience becoming the FCC chairman. You have said that experience provided you with all that was necessary to do a good job.

TOM WHEELER: Absolutely.

CHARLIE ROSE: He said, why would we let someone who`s been trying to lobby the FCC become the person who chairs the FCC? Is that some inherent conflict?

TOM WHEELER: Well, I think that, you know, if you go back and you look -- and, Charlie, I ran the Cable Television Association when it was an up and coming industry being and fighting for its survival. I ran the cellular industry, you know, a dozen years ago when it was an entirely different business.

I`ve started my own businesses. I have been a partner to venture capital firm helping start businesses. So I come to this job with an understanding of both business and policy and how it works with the people that we regulate. So I actually think I come with a leg up.

CHARLIE ROSE: What do you hope you accomplish while you`re chairman of the FCC? You addressed net neutrality. You have some mergers you have addressed.

TOM WHEELER: At the core, it is competition, you know. I mean the consumer`s best friend is a competitive market, and our broadband market isn`t as competitive as it could be. So, one of the reasons that you have an open Internet rule is to increase competition.

One of the reasons that we turned down the Comcast merger was to increase competition. One of the reasons that we have encouraged -- we pre-empted states -- let me just say -- one of the things the big providers were doing were going to state legislatures and getting them to pass laws that prohibited cities from building a competitive product if their people wanted them to. And we said no. That`s anti-competitive and so we pre- empted that.

MEG WHITMAN: He did and he was an incredible mentor to me. In fact, he came on the board of eBay and was a big -- he might be one of the best strategists in America today, business strategist. And he was a huge help to me at Bane and actually made an enormous difference to us.

CHARLIE ROSE: but what`s the philosophy here that people need -- somebody come in to the door and say this is what you`re not doing and this is what you don`t perceive and this is an intervention moment?

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. Well, I think sometimes and I think all of us are guilty of this at one time or another is, you begin to drink your own Kool- Aid and you don`t see yourself and your leadership style as it really is. And sometimes you need a friend or someone who works for you or a colleague to say do you see what you`re doing here? Do you see what you are doing?

CHARLIE ROSE: Was it the right idea to run for governor? Was that a mistake? Did somebody not come in to you and say Meg, this is a different game?

MEG WHITMAN: Yes.

CHARLIE ROSE: This is a political game?

MEG WHITMAN: They did say that.

CHARLIE ROSE: And why did you ignore that?

MEG WHITMAN: I think for a couple of reasons. One I saw the state that I loved, the state that had been my home for nearly 30 years was in real trouble. You might recall we had a huge budget deficit. We had a massive unfunded pension liability which by the way the state still has. Our education system had gone from number one in the country in the 50s to number 48 or 49 in, you know --

(CROSSTALK)

CHARLIE ROSE: -- and others were --

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. I mean and you just --

CHARLIE ROSE: At the university level.

MEG WHITMAN: -- yes and you have all kinds of challenges. I said maybe I can apply some of what I learned in my career both at eBay and other places to help solve some these problems. So I dove in with 100 percent of my effort, and I worked at it very had for almost two and a half years.

CHARLIE ROSE: But were you prepared to spend your own money as you are as Donald Trump is spending his own money?

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. I was prepared to do that.

CHARLIE ROSE: You spent a lot of your money.

MEG WHITMAN: I did. And I thought, you know, that -- and I also raised a lot of money. So I had a lot of support from people around the state, but I did spend some of my own money because it was important. I had to learn a lot, right. You know, I had to learn water policy. I had to learn education policy and it was an experience of a lifetime, Charlie.

CHARLIE ROSE: How`s Governor Brown doing?

MEG WHITMAN: Listen, he`s raised taxes, obviously, on a number of folks. The budget deficit is more in line than it was. It`s much smaller than it was. Silicon Valley has been a big help to that, right. Silicon Valley right now is the economic engine of California.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yes. And it`s the place that every foreign head of state wants to go because they want to create their own Silicon Valley.

MEG WHITMAN: Silicon Valley -- exactly.

CHARLIE ROSE: Xi Jinping went from Seattle, Washington before he went to Washington, D.C.

MEG WHITMAN: Exactly. Exactly. Because everyone loves this notion of how do you -- how could you possibly create Silicon Valley in China and --

CHARLIE ROSE: Can you? Or is that something you could do with America`s culture?

MEG WHITMAN: I don`t know. It`s really hard -- Charlie. It`s alchemy, almost. It`s the -- you have to have a great company like Hewlett-Packard which was the founder of Silicon Valley, a fantastic university or universities -- Stanford being the anchor, but Berkeley, Santa Clara, you know, U.C. Santa Cruz are all part of that ecosystem now. And then you have to have that venture capital where risk is rewarded.

And so it`s -- the more entrepreneurs you have, the more venture capital that`s attracted, the more great companies that start. And you start a positive -- it`s almost an ecosystem and it`s very hard to create.

CHARLIE ROSE: Do you worry that somehow there is the seed within the tech world today for overheating and a bubble that would burst?

MEG WHITMAN: Sure, I do. I do. I mean we lived through -- when I was at eBay, we lived through the 2001 bubble that burst. Frankly, eBay was fine because we had real revenues and real profits. And while our market cap went down a bit, we just kept on kept on going. But you know, you see a lot of very high multiples, young companies today. And so I worry about it.

And you`ve seen a pullback actually in the last six to eight weeks. You`ve seen a pullback in the valuation of some of these younger companies. So the multiples have gone down -- you know, we`ll see. I think the goodness is there is enough people who lived through 2001 who know what can happen.

CHARLIE ROSE: Who raised the questions?

MEG WHITMAN: But there is a whole generation that didn`t live through 2001 and sometimes you have to have -- you know, your question about running for governor -- you have to be a product of your experiences.

And by the way, I think I`m a better CEO because I ran.

CHARLIE ROSE: Because you understand the public dimension.

MEG WHITMAN: I understand the public dimension but also I learned a lot about communicating with large groups of people. And as it turned out by complete coincidence, when I came to HP, it happened to be about the same size as the government of California. And what I learned about communicating in politics is -- and I bet you know this -- it is not always about the left brain, the facts and the figures and all of this. It is about the emotion, the stories you tell and how you connect.

CHARLIE ROSE: Absolutely. It`s the emotional level that you connect and then people are there. If you connect on the emotional level then they`re open to your arguments.

MEG WHITMAN: Exactly. And I don`t think I completely understood that because when you grow a big business you are trained to be very analytical. I mean can you imagine being the CEO of a public company, going in front of your investors and telling them stories? I mean you would be thrown out on your ear. They want to know the numbers. They want to know the return on investment capital.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

MEG WHITMAN: And so we`re trained --

CHARLIE ROSE: If you say, let me tell you my narrative they say, what`s your bottom line?

MEG WHITMAN: They feel like excuse me. And so I was a very left-brained, trained individual, we all are. And, so, I had to learn a lot about communication. And so when I came to HP I learned about that and I did quite a different style of communication when I was trying to rally the whole company and the importance of symbolic value.

I`ll tell you a story about Jerry Brown and this is a story I admire him. When the state was in tremendous financial difficulty, he said you know what we`re going to do. We`re going to take the cell phones away from all the civil servants in the state of California. I remember thinking, OK, that`s all very interesting but it is 0.01 percent of the budget.

It wasn`t about the money. It was about the symbol and symbolism and the story he was telling which was he`s going to be tougher on the budget.

CHARLIE ROSE: -- and demand sacrifice.

MEG WHITMAN: Exactly. If you had asked the man on the street, you know, how do you think Jerry Brown is doing with the budget? He would have said doing great, taking away the cell phones from those civil servants.

CHARLIE ROSE: It was a symbolic act --

MEG WHITMAN: Exactly.

CHARLIE ROSE: that connected and resonated.

MEG WHITMAN: And so I learned while -- when I watched him. And so when I came to HP, I said what`s a symbolic act that I can do that will communicate to the company about why this is different. So the very first thing we did we tore town the executive parking lot and the barbed wire that surrounded the executive parking lot and I moved the entire leadership team to cubicles out of their wooden offices.

CHARLIE ROSE: They`re no longer behind closed doors or whatever?

MEG WHITMAN: We were out in the open just like everybody else. And we didn`t write about that. We didn`t make a publicity statement. 250,000 -- 300,000 HP people knew that within about 24 hours. And that made a statement.

CHARLIE ROSE: Breaking down the barriers between --

MEG WHITMAN: And I learned that from running for office.

CHARLIE ROSE: -- employer and employee.

MEG WHITMAN: Yes.

CHARLIE ROSE: You are supporting Governor Christie.

MEG WHITMAN: I am.

CHARLIE ROSE: Why?

MEG WHITMAN: I know Governor Christie quite well and I have admired what he has been able to do as a Republican governor in a blue state with a Democratically-controlled legislature. And my view is we have to have people who have learned to reach across the aisle and get things done. And he hasn`t gotten --

CHARLIE ROSE: That`s what`s needed in Washington, you`re suggesting?

MEG WHITMAN: I think that`s what`s needed in Washington because I think that it`s likely that the president will be one party and the congress will be of another. And so he didn`t get everything he wanted in New Jersey but sometimes in politics perfect is the enemy of really pretty good.

CHARLIE ROSE: How do you ascertain how he`s doing?

MEG WHITMAN: Well, he`s working very hard. And I think he is a fantastic retail politician. You know when we were talking about how you reach in and connect? No one`s better than Chris Christie at reaching in and connecting with people. When people interact with him, they feel like they know him and they understand his heart.

And so he`s been putting a lot of shoe leather into Iowa, into Nevada, into New Hampshire and I think he`s making progress. You can see him begin to inch up at the polls, you know. His favorables are turning. So I`m optimistic. But it`s a tough, tough slog. But I think he`s doing everything he knows how to do and I admire him a lot for doing it.

CHARLIE ROSE: Look at where we are in terms of technology. What`s next if you`re asked?

MEG WHITMAN: We`re still at the beginning of the mobile revolution. That sounds crazy because we`ve all had mobile phones for a long time but pretty soon almost everyone on the planet may have a mobile phone and it`s changing every element of life and I think we`re at the beginning of that impact not at the end.

And you think about how people use their phone in developing countries to, you know, trade commodities, to you know, sell their goods on the Internet to countries around the world. I mean it`s really phenomenal.

CHARLIE ROSE: And it gives people in faraway places access to all kinds of information.

MEG WHITMAN: It does and it has a political, you know, undercurrent as well. So I think we`re at the beginning of that revolution.

CHARLIE ROSE: -- which includes social media.

MEG WHITMAN: Well, social media is its home. Its first home really in many ways today is on your mobile. Yes, you know, Facebook was invented for the desktop but now there`s more people who access Facebook on their mobile than on their desktop.

So I just think you`re at the beginning of a tremendous revolution. When you think about a PC, per se, think about it, what you have in your hand is more powerful than a PC was ten years ago, it`s maybe more powerful than a PC was five years ago. Think about what you can do on your mobile, what you can do on your tablet.

Now, when you`ve got a lot of work to do, you really do want a full-fledged PC, but I think we`re at the beginning of that revolution.

CHARLIE ROSE: Is there a lesson to be learned from what Lou Gerstner did at IBM?

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. So I read his book with great interest as you will recall it was called "Who Says Elephants Can`t Dance". He said when he came to IBM at the end of his book he said when I came to IBM I thought culture was important. When I left IBM, he said I thought culture maybe was the only thing that`s important. And I can see exactly what he means.

CHARLIE ROSE: Why does it take so hard to learn that? I mean --

MEG WHITMAN: You know, because you think that other things can make a difference, but in the end when you run these big-scale operations, people on the frontlines, the sales person in New York for the server business has to know what to do, has to know what the ethics and the value and the ethos of the company is. And people have to -- it cannot be a command and control environment. People have to know what to do on the front lines. And how do they know what to do? It`s not through policy and procedures and handbooks, it`s through the culture.

CHARLIE ROSE: What did you learn from Steve Jobs at Apple, going back to a company that was on his --

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. Steve Jobs may well be the genius in business of my generation. I mean this guy was amazingly creative, and the ability to invent category.

CHARLIE ROSE: The company was near bankruptcy and now the largest company in the world.

MEG WHITMAN: It`s amazing. I mean it`s the biggest turnaround if you will that I`ve ever seen in my career. And they continue to amaze. And kudos to Tim Cook for being able to continue that legacy because it`s not easy to follow Steve Jobs.

CHARLIE ROSE: Why was it a mistake for Dell to buy EMC? That`s what you said to your employees. They gave you guys an opportunity.

MEG WHITMAN: Yes, exactly.

CHARLIE ROSE: Figuring out how to put cultures together and all that and you guys would go out there and start innovating.

MEG WHITMAN: Exactly. So listen it`s a fascinating time in history because two companies who are quite similar in many ways, HP was a larger company than Dell, but we were in largely the same businesses. We have taken took diametrically opposed strategies with the same set of facts. Right? So we decided --

CHARLIE ROSE: What were the facts?

MEG WHITMAN: Well, the industry and incredible tectonic plate shifts from, if you will, the old style of IT to the next generation. One of these inflection points for our industry where a lot of the old proud companies were under pressure. Our strategy was de-lever the balance sheet so you have no debt on the operating company, in fact you have cash on the operating company.

Lean in to new technology like three par, like our networking business, like Cloud. Make sure we pivoted to solution selling with our enterprise services business and really focus on revenue growth.

And their strategy was lever up the balance sheet, put old technology together, take out the costs and then try to make your way that way. I mean two diametrically opposed strategies.

Listen, I`m going to vote for Hewlett Packard Enterprise all day long because I think fast is important, speed is important where we live. And I`ll tell you -- they have a year to close the deal and another year to integrate. And we have an opportunity I think to explain to customers our solutions and why we are, you know, a stable, great company to do business with.

And it is pretty funny, Charlie, because you think back in 2011 we looked pretty unstable, right?

CHARLIE ROSE: Of course.

MEG WHITMAN: And now we`re looking like the paragon of stability.

CHARLIE ROSE: Was than when -- when did Fiorina leave?

MEG WHITMAN: Much earlier. I think 2005 --

CHARLIE ROSE: You went through her then you went through before that --

MEG WHITMAN: Right. I think Carly left in 2005, 2006 -- something like that.

CHARLIE ROSE: So has she taken an unfair hit or is it simply a product of she happened to be not the right person at the right time for Hewlett Packard?

MEG WHITMAN: So listen, politics is tough, right. We covered this. I mean it is tough. You`ve got to have a rhinoceros skin, and people will try to take you on. I would like to say no good deed goes unpunished. And I said before in public, I think the Compaq acquisition was the right thing. We have the position that we have today in PCs and in servers thank you to the Compaq acquisition.

CHARLIE ROSE: She drove that.

MEG WHITMAN: And she drove that. And she drove that.

CHARLIE ROSE: And it was right thing?

MEG WHITMAN: I think it was the right thing. With 20/20 hindsight looking back, I`m glad we have the position that we have in those two businesses because fundamentally they are the bedrock now of HP, Inc. and Hewlett Packard enterprises.

CHARLIE ROSE: When you buy a business, I mean you see people -- they`ll buy company just to get the CEO -- to get the executive talent.

MEG WHITMAN: Yes. Yes. In Silicon Valley, they`re called acqui-hires, you know, acquisition of hires.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right, right. Acqui-hire.

MEG WHITMAN: An acqui-hire. People would say for the most part these big tech acquisitions are very tough to pull off and usually there is a challenge before, you know, the sun rises again. So, you know, listen I think we`re super well-prepared in these two companies to go own innovate, deliver for customers in a changing world, while we`re not trying to integrate another company. We`re not trying to, you know, fundamentally remake the sales force and take out hundreds of millions of dollars of cost.

CHARLIE ROSE: Thank you for coming.

MEG WHITMAN: Thank you.

CHARLIE ROSE: Great to see you.

MEG WHITMAN: Great to see you again. Thank you -- Charlie.

CHARLIE ROSE: Meg Whitman.

Thank you for joining us. See you next time.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

urn:contentItem:5KRW-K121-DY0W-43PV-00000-00Conversation with Tom Wheeler; Conversation with Meg Whitman2015-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:26ZLexisNexisConversation with Tom Wheeler; Conversation with Meg WhitmanLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHARLIE ROSE: Welcome to the program.

Tonight: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM WHEELER, FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION CHAIRMAN: I ran the Cable Television Association when it was an up and coming industry being and fighting for survival. I ran the cellular industry, you know, a dozen years ago when it was an entirely different business. I've started my own businesses. I have been a partner to venture capital firm helping start businesses.

So I come to this job with an understanding of both business and policy and how it works with the people that we regulate. So I actually think I come with a leg up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: We conclude with Meg Whitman, formerly the CEO of eBay, now the CEO of Hewlett Packard.

MEG WHITMAN, HEWLETT PACKARD CEO: I found a very proud company with incredible founder DNA. The a-ha here is, and this is great news for any founder that's watching your program, it is really hard to kill founder DNA.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yes.

MEG WHITMAN: And for HP, that was a very good thing because the core of this company through all the acquisitions and all the board drama was around innovation and focus on customers.

And so I made the decision, let's do more of what we do well, and then we'll work on the to-do list of things that need to be fixed. And there were a number of things that need to be fixed.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE ROSE: Tom Wheeler and Meg Whitman, when we continue.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: From our studios in New York City, this is CHARLIE ROSE.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHARLIE ROSE: Tom Wheeler is here. He is chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. The agency adopted net neutrality rules earlier this year. The new regulations treat Internet service as a public utility. The commissioner has also been active in reviewing media and telecommunications mergers.

This summer it approved AT&T's takeover of DirecTV which created the largest television distributor in the United States. Next year the FCC will hold an auction to coordinate the sale of television air waves.

For all those reasons I'm pleased to have Chairman Tom Wheeler at this table for the first time. It seems like I've known him for 100 years. It's a pleasure to have you.

TOM WHEELER: Charlie -- thank you. It's great to be here.

CHARLIE ROSE: And we had your favorite Ohio State coach here the other day and --

TOM WHEELER: From the Ohio State University.

CHARLIE ROSE: From the Ohio State University. My impression is they have no bigger or stronger fan than you.

TOM WHEELER: I think that's a true statement.

CHARLIE ROSE: Yes. And you used to work with Woody Hayes.

TOM WHEELER: Yes, way back when, when I was in graduate school I had the privilege of being able to rub shoulders with Coach Hayes and some of the things he was doing in the state. He was a great --

CHARLIE ROSE: I would imagine you had lots to talk about military history and all the things that he taught there.

TOM WHEELER: Yes. And three yards and a cloud of dust -- that's the way he ran. You know, three things can -- why don't you pass coach? Three things can happen and two of them were bad.

CHARLIE ROSE: So what can happen to the FCC?

TOM WHEELER: Well, you know, Charlie we're sitting at a really exciting time in history if you stop and think about it. The most important external force in our daily lives are the networks that connect us, and we at the FCC get the privilege to be involved in the evolution of those networks into the digital era, whether it's broadcasting or cable or satellite or telephone networks or the Internet. That's our jurisdiction.

It's about a sixth of the economy that we get a chance to participate with as they're evolving from the old analog world to the new digital world.

CHARLIE ROSE: And so -- but what do you do? I mean you obviously hear important arguments and make rulings on them.

TOM WHEELER: Well, you know, the really interesting thing about this job is that the statute was written in 1934. It was updated in 1996. And even from 1996, a lot has changed. So the challenge that we have is to say, OK, let's look at the basic four corners that the Congress has laid down and said this is what we think is in the public interest, and then make interpretations as to how that statutory responsibility works in the new digital world.

And so we're dealing with everything from mergers to competitive issues and how do you make sure that there is competition in these markets? How do you make sure that there is consumer protection? How do you make sure that national security is protected? So it's a very broad palette that we have to work with.

CHARLIE ROSE: This is what predecessor Michael Powell, president of the National Cable Communications Association and the chairman of the FCC in the Bush administration said quote, "The commission has breathed new life into the decayed telephone regulatory model and applied it to the most dynamic free wheeling and innovative platform in history."

TOM WHEELER: Well, I agree totally with him. The Internet is the most dynamic and free wheeling platform in history.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

TOM WHEELER: It's the most powerful and pervasive platform in history.

I disagree entirely with him because on his other part because, basically, what the cable industry and the telephone industry and those who provide Internet service, last-mile service, have been saying is, oh, leave us alone, leave us alone.

What we did was we said, wait a minute -- there is a basic responsibility that people who are providing Internet service have to make sure that consumers have unfettered access to the content they want to go to on the web and that those who are creating content have unfettered access to consumers, and that's some basic things.

There should be no blocking. You should not be able to say you can get through when you can't. There should be no throttling. You shouldn't be able to say, well, your service, I'm not going to allow it to go as fast as another service. There should be no paid prioritization. You shouldn't be able to say well, you're a fast lane and you're a slow lane, because you're paying me more.

And then what you need to have in place is I think the thing that they're really most concerned about and that is you need to have a referee on the field. We were talking about Woody Hayes and Urban Meyer a minute ago.

CHARLIE ROSE: That's one of the arguments they made.

CHARLIE ROSE: OK. But their argument is that you inhibit innovation. That's where they --

CHARLIE ROSE: 83 percent?

TOM WHEELER: 83 percent.

CHARLIE ROSE: Right.

TOM WHEELER: But two-thirds of those can get it from only one company. So the goal is how do you facilitate competition? Because competition drives prices down, competition incentivizes better service, competition is a consumer's friend with innovation.

CHARLIE ROSE: Speaking of mergers -- trying to understand how you approach these and how you make a judgment about competition, there was a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile.

TOM WHEELER: Right, and we actively discouraged that, that four wireless carriers is a good and vibrant market, and if you were to take number three and number four and allow them to merge to go to three, that would have hurt --

CHARLIE ROSE: But would it have made them stronger and therefore be more competitive because there is a difference.

TOM WHEELER: But look at what's happened --

CHARLIE ROSE: there is a difference between those four. And if three and four could combine and therefore be more competitive with one and two, why isn't at that a good idea?

CHARLIE ROSE: No, we have not had harmonization with the rest of the world in some cases -- have we?

CHARLIE ROSE: OK.

TOM WHEELER: Right.

CHARLIE ROSE: To what though?

CHARLIE ROSE: Exactly. Yes, right.

CHARLIE ROSE: It's a content company.

CHARLIE ROSE: What is that future?

CHARLIE ROSE: You bid on them.

TOM WHEELER: Nobody has ever tried. You bid on them and pay the government. And nobody has ever tried that. But that's really -- it is letting the market work to put spectrum to its highest and best use. And it's going to be ground-breaking, and I think it will be the future of how --

CHARLIE ROSE: How will you mark success?

TOM WHEELER: We'll mark success by whether new spectrum gets opened, you know.
